commentBody:
I definitely agree with Sam that MOUTH ORGAN is the outlier here, and although it doesn't violate any rules, the fact that ORGAN is a general term and not a specific body part makes that entry rather inelegant.

HEART EYES was inferrable, but I've personally never heard that term (but I have seen the emoji).

MUSCLEHEAD was fine, but KNUCKLEHEAD would have been better.

ICES OVER works better with lakes than windows.  I'd say the latter ice shut. In fact, I did say that, but I had to delete it.

I found HTML in this puzzle and HTTP in the Mini interesting.

That's all I got.

Crossword Revolution Day 21:  SEA LEGS

Starting to get mine back.  Enough to attempt a SESTET below.

A Crosswords Saved the Day ‚Ñ¢ production.
I think the heart-eyes emoji is one of those round yellow faces except that the eyes are hearts instead of black dots.üòç
Who else had BD_M and wondered exactly what type of real estate they were selling?

"Where are your anatomy notes?"
"Not sure. Have to get organ-ized."

("Nice pun. Humerus with some more of them.")

I liked that the theme answers work directly as clued, so you may not notice the theme til you hit the revealer.

Lots of pleasant word choices too, especially "bring to bear" for exert.

Is it just me or was there something vaguely suggestive about this puzzle? There's that muscle-head Atlas dancing solo at the disco in Reno, you make come-hither heart-eyes at him, slip him a note that simply says "Bdrm?" along with your spare room key. Take me as I am, you say when he comes a-calling, and then it's all a blur -- off with his Tommy Bahamas, minty breath, aloe and balsam, something he called oral-b and you called mouth organ, then something else about the leaning tower of Pisa, and Si Si Si! and Ol√©, Ol√©, Ol√©! and Ahh! Ahh! Ahh!...& when it was all over and the two of you lay enlaced like two little pupples, your hands back behind your heads, it was like ESP: you both said at the same time "Well YOU certainly brought your A-game!" like you were both the kind of professor who hands back grades for things like that. Then Atlas put back on his wrinkled Versace suit, said "See ya!" while you lay there in bed, lost in revery, thinking: does anyone ever take tees as souvenirs? What kind of a weirdo would get back from a vacation and look at the souvenir tees from the Irish golfcourse on the edge of the Shannon? What kind of a life is that? And also about Atlas; you had looked in his wallet during a trip to the loo; his license read Atlas Carlo O'Neal. What kind of parents would name their kid Atlas? Wouldn't that exert a lot of pressure on the tyke?
Si Si was a bit of lazy clueing imho

I noticed the body parts, but didn't really see a strong connection between the theme answers. Having one plural word at the beginning, another as the end, with the other two answers being all singular bothered me a bit, along with the generality of ORGAN rather than there being a specifically named body part.

It still worked as a decent Tuesday puzzle, but I wasn't particularly thrilled with the theme.

I miss the era when BTS was just everywhere. Those boys are so wholesome and nice.  My daughter is still crazy about them. She also has been singing every Alicia Keys song since she was four. I mean belting them out!

ISSARAE is one beautiful and talented person üòç. I‚Äôll watch anything she plays in or produces. I‚Äôd hoped that her role of President Barbie would have been prescient but, *sigh* that was not to be.

I don‚Äôt hear MEWS coming out of our litter boxes, just scratching and litter getting CAST onto the floor. It‚Äôs a small price to pay for all the purrs and snuggles üòª.

There could have been a great theme here. Like maybe involving the phrase ‚Äúbody double.‚Äù As it is, this one was awkward and clunky. A lot of it was absurdly easy but then cluing LAY as ‚ÄúBallad‚Äù was very Fri/Sat and tripped me up for a long time. Not a fan.

And all is fine in the world. 

Nice Tuesday 

Thanks
I was starting to wonder is real estate shared an acronym with BDSM as I had EXIST. For the best for a lot of realtors out there
'Mayday'....Hellman's

TIL LAY

Not willing to try my luck in the emu filter, adding some padding.

Meh. The theme did nothing for me, possibly because of my ignorance and slow wit, but still, for me there was no enjoyment to be had. I've never heard of TWO PART harmony, and besides, a body part is not just *a part*. I needed the column to get what was going on.

There were also some sections of the puzzle that to me felt too hard for a Tuesday, like the one in the middle on the bottom of the puzzle, with two abbreviations next to one another. BD*M... Srsly? I only saw one letter there, obviously the wrong one.

When I filled the grid having needed three lookups, I did not get my happy music. By this time (and it was Wednesday time) I was too annoyed by the whole thing to look for my mistake so I just checked the puzzle to be done with it. I had made a typo, but I don't regret not taking my tike to spot it.

BTW, Polish classified ads for real estate feature abbreviations too, but different ones, some even more arcane than the American ones, possibly. Over here traditionally not the number of bedrooms was listed but the number of rooms in general. Thus M3 meant an apartment with 3 rooms, with the M coming from "mieszkanie", our word for apartment. For decades M3 was standard accommodation for a typical family of parents plus two or three kids. The shortest Warsaw real estate classified ad from 30 years ago I can imagine would be something like: "M3 Wola 75000 [phone number]" (Wola is part of town in Warsaw).
At first, I thought reviewers hATED movies, but then I realized they just RATED them.

Looks like the missing entry should be SORE HEADS.  I enjoyed solving the puzzle (listening to a Warriors game, and more into that instead of kneecapping the fills), and I was surprised to see such a chorus of dissatisfaction when I came to the Comments.

Mr. E. got a LOT more out of it than I did (nice jigsawing the fills into that steamy tale!), but I still found it Tuesday-worthy.

Thank you, Paul Coulter, and don't let the 
ü¶Éü¶Éü¶Éü¶Éü¶É get you down.

Tonight I was a full on MUSCLEHEAD. Could not figure out the bottom of this puzzle for anything. 3 mins over my average. Probably my slowest Tues in months. I just wasn't on the right wavelength with this puzzle. I couldn't even get AS I AM an album I've listened to beginning to end more times than I can recall. It was a struggle, but I'm done.

just PARTS felt a bit vague/general to be the revealer. would've liked a more direct reference to human organs. I liked charles from NYC's suggestion of 'BODYDOUBLE'

-----
jackie & shadow 4ever
Mouth Organ - a redundancy, surely...
Got hung up by having SEXTET instead of SESTET and not having heard of LAY as a type of ballad.  So I couldn't get to EYES as the last part of HEARTEYES.

Strands #345
‚Äú"Attention all shoppers"‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµüîµ


Announce no spoilers until after the View All Replies button please.

Slow solve for me today. For whatever reason, I got more stuck today than Friday and Saturday from last week. It took me a hot minute to get the theme. It was harder for me than most Tuesdays. I liked the challenge though! I may be alone in the slow uptake.

I found the top half solved quickly, fortunately got BTS from the crossers. Yes, I know it's been in before. Maybe, like BAMA, I'll start to remember it.
The MOUTH ORGAN or 'mouthie' was very popular when I was a child. Cheap, not overly difficult to get a tune out of.
Some of the bottom half was trickier. I didn't get MUSCLE HEAD for ages, didn't know the actress or the very famous album. I read Asunci√≥n as Ascension and tried for a religious connotation. As for the ice cream man .....
As with many Scottish houses in the 50's and 60's, we only had coal fire heating in one room and in the winter bedroom windows (and bathroom) would sometimes ICE OVER on the inside.

The caption under the puzzle picture reminds me of a humorous phrase:

It goes without saying, but bears repeating that ‚Ä¶ 

On a totally different topic, can someone enlighten me on the second part of the label on the toggle that says, ‚ÄúEmail me when my comment is published and if a journalist responds‚Äù?  

All I can think of is that it may be a NYT universal toggle when one sends an e-mail to someone on the writing staff of the newspaper.

Nice puzzle, Paul! Today marks the first day I was able to fill in BTS without thinking. For some reason, even though it pops up over and over, I had a mental block and could never remember it. The last time it appeared, a post -solve look up revealed that it meant Bulletproof Boy Scouts. That wasn't going to help, so I made up my own reminder: big teen sensation. It felt good writing it in without a cross. And for MOUTH ORGAN? *This* is what it's all about: https://youtu.be/jU8m5-FOc38?si=ONpZ3_DQMUZXRoYb
Thanks for the note on 6D!  Like you I only got it through the crossings and had no idea what it meant. You saved me from having to do the research!

Just a bit on the tough side for a Tuesday for me. A lot of working the crosses but managed to get it all eventually. And... must admit that I wasn't grasping the theme at all until I was done and reviewed and pondered for a bit. No big deal. And... this type of theme has been done before. A Monday from May 24, 2021 by Adrienne Atkins. The reveal in that one was: "Stand-in during a film shoot ... or a hint to 17-, 25-, 38- and 51-Across" BODYDOUBLE And those theme answers: MOUTHORGAN RIBJOINT KNUCKLEHEAD BACKLASH Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/11/2025 I'll put my other puzzle find in a reply. ....
It's a good day when the first clue you see is BTS üíúüíúüíú Lovely puzzle, I enjoyed the theme and got it fairly quickly.
Me too on LAY!!!

Woke up to this light and breezy puzzle,
and the coolest husband on the planet,
who I married 30 years ago, today.

As I walked in to the kitchen,
Bruce Springsteen‚Äôs ‚ÄúI Wanna Marry You‚Äù
was playing.

It‚Äôs a *very* good day for this lucky gal.

Thank you Paul!

Happy Tuesday all!

Well, my brain likes to crack riddles, and because I often don‚Äôt catch on to things quickly, it had a good workout trying to figure out why TWO PART hinted toward the theme answers.  Finally, finally, came ‚ÄúOh!  PART as in body part!‚Äù  

I am an enigma unto myself.  I often without effort crack deviously misdirecting and arcane clues, while the obvious often soars over my head.  

I loved the clue [Add years to one‚Äôs life] for AGE, as well as the long-O northeast and southeast corners.  I popped MOUTH ORGAN in, a term I haven‚Äôt come across or thought about in decades.  MUSCLEHEAD triggered lovely images of Caroll O‚ÄôConnor as Archie Bunker, who constantly called Rob Reiner‚Äôs character (Michael Stivic) ‚Äúmeathead‚Äù.  

It was sweet to see AHH PEACE in row two; my whole body relaxes every time I look at that.

So, Paul, I left the box with a lot more than I came into it with ‚Äì a gift.  Thank you so much for making this!

What is the meaning of 60D?   ‚ÄúCan‚Äù solves to AXE? I‚Äôve stared at it for 15 minutes and have no idea.  

Also, can‚Äôt say I was a fan of BDRM.  Seemed very much forced into the puzzle.

Yes, always hoping it will ice over during that little ‚Äúwinter window‚Äù of late October, November, December, January, February, March, and early April.

 (At least body parts stay warmer when paired up.)

The fill seemed especially solid, but MOUTHORGAN kinda ruined the theme for me. MUSCLEHEAD too, but less so. Both ORGAN and MUSCLE seemed too generic.

Nice effort, but, to me, not a viable theme. 

LIked the vertical stack in the NW: BAHAMAS, THENILE, SHANNON, especially because SHANNON was clued geographically.
Are the Teamsters no longer the biggest union?
Enjoyed this one very much. Very cool theme!

That was good, I was lucky to notice the body parts theme fairly quickly and use it to scaffold other parts of the grid.
Not an enormous fan of the "si si" entry though, since Paraguay is pretty famous for being a rare (if not unique) South American country with more speakers of its main indigenous language than the colonial alternative.
Overall, a satisfying and very nicely-made Tuesday puzzle, thanks!

A slightly chewy Tuesday, but nothing too indigestible.  Album, film director and group needed crossings. I really should know BTS by now, though I always start with BST as in British Summer Time. Catches me out every time.
Needed to stand back and look at BDRM to get it. Don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs a common abbreviation here, fairly sure you get a bed symbol online and the full word in print.
I long for the days you got an actual 46D. It‚Äôs always KEY cards now that take forever to hit the green light.

Off to book club this afternoon, one of my favourite activities‚Ä¶after the crossword of course.

An odd solve for me today as I had a difficult time finding a toe-hold at first and I thought it was going to be one of those Wednesday-on-a-Tuesday sort of puzzles but once I found a way in, it went fairly smoothly, though chaotically as I jumped all over the grid to finish. When I did, I was surprised to see my time was roughly 40 percent faster than my average. Still, I appreciated the clues that made me sweat a bit: 11D (Good standing for a sailor); 38D (Band aid). Also, TIL that there is a song form called LAY.

So, thank you, Paul Coulter.

I was completely flummoxed by LAY to the point where this puzzle was a staring contest between me and 4A due to that hole. The rest was fairly smooth, but I don't think I found the theme as amusing as intended. Still, always appreciate a slightly tougher Tuesday than usual to ramp up for the rest of the week!

I'd like a show of hands for who else popped PEG LEGS into 11D without hesitating....  even if the plural should have warned us off.

MUSCLEHEAD?  SRSLY?
And don't we just call them 'compound words' without need for further explication?

There are also bedding plants called BALSAM (quite pretty bordering one's driveway.)  Just so  you know.  In case you get ambitious.  In seed catalogs (which have already arrived in the mail.)

Fun Tuesday‚Äîfast but a little chewy in parts, and for me, the most challenging clues were held in check by accessible crosses. I really admire the editing and construction work that must go into something like that. Thank you for this fun diversion, Mr. Coulter & ed‚Äôs!

While I‚Äôm here though, I‚Äôd like to also defend the use of this space to air less than positive feelings about other  puzzles. Sunday‚Äôs, for instance, I thought was a bit dull compared to our usual fare. I don‚Äôt usually post my thoughts if a puzzle isn‚Äôt great, but in this case, the constructors were both veterans, what I was saying wasn‚Äôt mean-hearted, and I felt comfortable offering the critique. 

In response to a similar post from someone else, a commenter asked: if you‚Äôre not enjoying the puzzle, why don‚Äôt you just stop doing it (instead, I presume, of complaining about it)? This bothered me.

I personally see puzzles as challenges, and I don‚Äôt like to turn away from a challenge once I‚Äôve begun‚Äîeven if the challenge is not as fun as I‚Äôd hoped it would be. Are enthusiastically engaged posts more fun to read? Sure! But‚Äîand I guess this is all I‚Äôm really saying here‚Äîthere are better ways to respond to honest, if less entertaining, comments.

A great puzzle -- just the right level for a Tuesday. I thought there might be some lookups, but the names of unfamiliar bands and actors were nicely filled in by the crosses.

At one point, I had filled in BD_M, thought, "No! Not in the NYT Crossword!" And sure enough, the answer was BDRM (doh). 

Once I let go of HTTP and put in HTML (another doh), it was all smooth sailing.

Did not even realize that the two-word theme answers were all two *body parts* until I read Sam Corbin's column (there were other two-word answers). 

May all Tuesday puzzles be like this.
Congratulations to the constructor. Let's see more from him!

P.S. Appreciated the cat-related clues (purrrrrrr).
LAY = ‚ÄúBallad‚Äù?  I guess I learned something, but sheesh.

Okay, what is going on over there?  This is a real problem - I have been trying to coax a couple of people into the crossword and this kind of unpredictability is making it impossible.  Mondays and Tuesdays are supposed to be easier.

This Tuesday puzzle was more difficult than EVERY puzzle last week, including Thursday through Sunday.  Lay for ballad?  Seriously?  Seriously??

Exert for bring to bear?  Pas for father figures?  Sestet?  The Shannon river?

All of these are Saturday level, if not just unwise cluing.

This inconsistency does not speak well of the editing.  This was supposed to be a Tuesday.  I was and am delighted that Will is back but we must have better than this.  Please.

(I haven't read the other comments yet; I hope I have some company.)

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

[Oh and the theme was fine.]

It was interesting to read Paul Coulter‚Äôs comments about the development of this puzzle and how it was rejected by all but the NYT.

I loved solving this one. Nice and thoughtful clueing throughout. Not difficult but with plenty of food for thought. I like puzzles, such as this one, that speak to the author‚Äôs brainpower and feel organic, rather than puzzles where the fill seems artificially sweetened with trivia gleaned from outside the head. I can sense the difference, actually solving the puzzle rather than just filling in the blanks.
I regret looking up BDSM for 56 down‚Ä¶

When and why did the Tuesday puzzle become so cutesy and more like Wednesday-Friday than Monday?  Some people like crosswords without the mental gymnastics.  I guess the bright side is I can finally stop subscribing after all these years and just do the WAPO puzzles.
Finally have a 30 day streak! I enjoyed this one.

Good Tuesday puzzle, in terms of degree of difficulty (IMHO).  YMMV.

The theme is decent, although not too terribly imaginative.  (Although I'm glad that it's not my job to think up original themes for these puzzles!  I know it can't be easy!)
 
My complaint is with the revealer.  It seems to me that it needs to have the word "body" in it in order to make sense.  For example, "Body parts" or "Body double" (which I learned has been done before).  TWO PART just doesn't do it for me.  I got it, but only after I had finished the puzzle and was puzzling out the theme.

I got the HEART EYES emoji because there were three of them as a clue for I LOVE IT just last week. I don't use emojis myself, but my 80 year old mother has started putting them in text messages. (I think her iPhone suggests them.)

6-Down?  Huh?

I‚Äôve been solving puzzles, usually fairly well, daily for over 50 years. 

Never saw that clue-answer relationship, and don‚Äôt understand it now.

I‚Äôm sure Barry Ancona, or someone else, will just say I‚Äôve missed it over the years, but I think I might not be alone in this gripe.

Overly forced theme with inconsistincies, switching between plural and singular body PARTS, when the theme was TWOPART. 

Other forced clues made this absurd for a Tuesday. "LAY" for "ballad?" Really?

In broad daylight, yesterday,
I read a Poet's mystic lay;
And it seemed to me at most
As a phantom, or a ghost. 

- Longfellow

I would have liked to have been a fly on the editors' wall when they were discussing [Ballad] for LAY (6D)on a Tuesday. No I didn't know it, despite knowing a lot of musical terms and having once been a big Middle Earth fan. Yes I was able to get it from crosses. Yes I enjoyed learning a new term. 

Fun fast solve, slightly faster than average. Enjoyed seeing the River SHANNON in the grid.

Heads up that a new movie just opened called HEART EYES. Just in time for Valentine's Day, it's a rom-com/slasher pic. I'll pass, but if any of y'all check it out, circle back with your review. thx.

Band aid unnecessarily annoyed me. Not as poor cluing or anything, just because I truly couldn't get my brain off of the brand name and into the other meanings. My own fault and a very FACEPALM solve, if you will. ;) I don't typically need a lookup on Tuesdays, but I struggled in the southwest corner until looking up the Alicia Keys album. 

Also: team 'don't really get the hate for LAY' check in here. I thought it an easy solve on crosses even if the definition was new to me.
6D is new to me. And, not being a fan of any music since the 70's, I was wondering why Ms. Keys would record an album called "Asian" (I worked it out).

I thought I had everything right and couldn't for the life of me figure out where I went wrong ‚Äî I begrudingly looked up the answer for 63-Across because it looked funky.

It was then I realized that I misread 53-Down ("Flings") as "Filings" ‚Äî this is what got me to change CASES to CASTS and wrap everything up.

I don't know if that was intentional, but I found it quite uncanny that misreading that clue by one letter caused a one-letter error in the solve that fit the misread clue.

Fast and lots of fun too. I really enjoyed it and I‚Äôm very surprised that it was rejected by so many. I‚Äôm glad you persevered, Paul Coulter. 
After reading only the latest few comments, I noticed several complaints about LAY. It is definitely in my wheelhouse, but it would be lovely if folks who haven‚Äôt heard of it would just add it to their list of discoveries instead of griping about it.

Sam! Thanks for the clip. Once Upon a Time in the West has to be one of my all time favorite movies, I hope you enjoyed it as much as I do. 

When Charles Bronson is standing in the doorway and says "Someday" I enter western genre movie nirvana.

Aside from that, a favorite book is Les Chants de Maldoror, Chants being translated as Songs, Dirges, and Lay. It is the only time I have ever seen lay in the sense of 6D, so I can understand why some people thought the clue pretty obscure.

I highly recommend the Sergio Leone movie, and strongly advise against reading Maldoror. The Alexis Lykiard translation is by far the best for those who do not know French, but that doesn't really matter as I'm certain you will heed my advice.

What constitutes a body part? I like heart, mouth, head and back. Not so crazy about eyes (two parts?), muscle, and hands. The theme would be a lot tighter with just simple single body parts.

Daily difficulty seems to be getting more random every day.
AHH nuts! 5 seconds off a PB, and it was due to a typo. Nice Tuesday puzzle!

So does this mean that all those years in high school when I was trying to get LAYd, that all I was really trying to do was get serenaded by a ballad?  Or serenade someone with a ballad?

I thought I was just lustful.

Just to weigh in and provide some feedback to the team...

I too found this to be unbalanced in a couple of ways. The top middle threw me because I barely see emojis and never heard of the word that means "ballad." 

So I second, third, and fourth guessed myself and would say that the difficulty really spiked in that area. But I see that this, as is usual, depended on what each of us knows. My ignorance made that very tough.

But like some others, I found the execution of the theme not very elegant. The revealer was logically insufficient (so to speak), and the combinations in the themed answers seemed to not have enough parallelism (for want of a better way of saying it).

So yeah, like some meals, it was okay but not that tasty. I thought I was a gourmand, but apparently not entirely.
Too hard for a Tuesday puzzle...waaah!
Good puzzle, I eventually got it without hints. Did feel more like a Wednesday though.
Hm.. why do Teamsters say they‚Äôre the largest union in the US? Regardless, tough Tuesday!
Another incredibly tough Tuesday, two in a row!
@Steve L I had HTTP in both puzzles... until it didn't work in this one. (And yeah, I know HTTP isn't "code.")

@Steve L 

Other than that, Mr. L,, how did you like the puzzle (or what was left of it)?
@Michael Weiland I blame the Mini for HTTP as my first entry. When that didn't fit, I reread the clue, or should I say actually read the clue. This was a challenging Tuesday !

@Steve L 
An organ, like a muscle, is a non specific body part. Isn‚Äôt it?

@Graphic 

ORGAN is less specific than MUSCLE.

Yes, Yes

Take me AS I AM and SEND HELP
My SEA LEGS feel as firm as kelp,
DOOM‚Äôs in the next ROOM and
I‚Äôm being come-HITHERed by gloom,
But HEAD and HEART are KEY,
HAND BACK hopelessness?  Si, Si!

@Vaer 

Nice!  It was a UB40 twofer in that section of the puzzle.
@David Meyers For what it's worth: I always have to think of a salami pizza when I see this emoji...
@Lou Scheffer i didn't even look at the clue and had to correct later
@Lou Scheffer I did look at the clue and still couldn't imagine anything but an S going in that blank space. I got the correct answer from the crossing entry. Never heard that term before.
@Lou Scheffer, yes I did, with "EXisT crossing it seemed almost plausible for a bit!
@Lou Scheffer I got the 3 letter through crosses. And I wondered. Bedrooms abreviated!

Mike,

Likely you could do 50 more anatomical puns.
But I liked your single shade of Grays.

(plus, you‚Äôve got avoid many bawdy parts).

@Mike 
I have a bone to pick with you, although I doubt my carpal do any good -- since you've already put this one into circulation, my attempt would be in vein.

@Mike 
It is almost impossible to forego disecting the body of your work, but I am rendered limb from laughter...
@john ezra I know a little kid named Atlas.  Yes, that‚Äôs my SOLO response to your comment ü§£.
@john ezra yep! I blushed at MOUTHORGAN and paused at BD_M‚Ä¶ among other things.
@john ezra now that you bring them so vividly back to mind, I think tees might be referring to shirts
@john ezra -- It started as just you, yes, but after reading this magnificent musing, it is me as well, and probably a host of others.

@Adin 

Ha! With my blinkered brain I didn't even think of that...of course it has to be t-shirts!

@john ezra 

üëèüèªüëèüèª üëèüèª

@Mady 

Yeah yeah
@mjengling  no no üòÄ

Mady,

Si Si wasn't a clue.
@Pani Korunova The new era of BTS being everywhere is upon  us! We just have a few more months until each of the seven has completed their military service.

@Pani Korunova - I think "Litter box" in this context is a box in which you keep a litter of kittens. 

A bit of misdirect, welcome for a Tuesday.
@Charles Nelson Reilly I liked the puzzle but agree odd cluing for LAY

@Charles Nelson Reilly The Lay of the Last Minstrel by Sir Walter Scott is a long narrative poem containing six Cantos. It's most well-known line is: "Breathes there the man, with soul so dead, Who never to himself hath said, This is my own, my native land! Whose heart hath ne'er within him burn'd, As home his footsteps he hath turn'd, From wandering on a foreign strand!" The whole poem TL;DR can be found here: https://www.theotherpages.org/poems/minstrel.html
@Charles Nelson Reilly -- "Body double" is a fantastic reveal for this puzzle!

One person's tricky clue may be another's gimme, but I'm always a bit sad when people push back on clues that are definitions of their answers. lay 4 of 5 noun (2) 1: a simple narrative poem : ballad https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/lay#dictionary-entry-4

@Darcey O‚ÄôD 

Spelling Bee won't take PELF.

@Darcey O‚ÄôD Lyrics to the Rescue!
I know "pelf" from PIPPIN, the song Simple Joys:

Well, I'll sing you the story of a sorrowful lad
He had everything he wanted
Didn't want what he had
He had wealth and pelf and name and fame
And all of that noise
But he didn't have none of those simple joys
His life seemed purposeless and flat
Aren't you glad you don't feel like that?
@Barry Ancona I learned something new today!  I wasn‚Äôt familiar with that definition of the word lay.

@Michael 

What?
@Jim .....Best part of lousy game.
@Hardroch üòè

@Andrzej
Would that be a bedroom for the parents, a bedroom for the kids, and then a combined kitchen/living area?

@Anne 

Living room - which often doubled as the parents' bedroom - and two bedrooms for the kids. Bathroom and kitchen - even though they were separate rooms from the sleeping/living areas - were not directly listed with this M3 shorthand. One just assumed they were there. Also, a kitchen area as part of the living area only became a thing in the 1990s here. Previously the kitchen was almost always a separate room.

@Andrzej In France the same idea is used, my apartment is a T2, or one bedroom. Kitchen, bath, toilet don't count, all other rooms do. I have no idea, however, what the T stands for! Maybe someone else does...
@Andrzej There's a play from 1972 called "6 Rms Riv Vu", for Six Rooms, River View.

@Bob T. 

My two favorite things together - the theater and American abbreviations ü§£

Big Box stores are usually built in the suburbs or outskirts of town, a big boxy building surrounded by parking, and often an array of smaller stores as satellite buildings or as part of a shopping plaza. Big box stores may be general stores like WalMart. Or they may be category-killers, in that they become almost monopolies in their product field, crowding out all the local businesses --- like Home Depot for hardware and buliding supplies, Staples for office supplies, PetSmart for pet supplies, or as Bed Bath & Beyond was for home goods.

There's a church that was built here several years ago that used commercial construction techniques, a large box framed in steel. Many locals called it the WalMart church, since that's what it looked like. The last touches of roofing, siding and landscaping finally made it look less commercial, more church-y.
(The church members did not like being called the WalMart church.)

@Jane Wheelaghan 

As for the ice cream man, indeed.  Joseph EDY and his partner, William Dreyer, were responsible for two supermarket ice cream brands in the US.  In the West, where the business began, the brand is known by its  original name,Dreyer's.  When they expanded eastward, they marketed the same product as EDYS, since there was already a similarly named brand, Breyer's, in the East.  

Given its common letters, one brand (and the eponymous owner's name) appears frequently in the puzzle (which of course comes from a city in the East).  Number of appearances: 51 for EDY, 98 for EDYS.

You should learn both names, though, because Dreyer is often in the clue.

We say "get the sack" from the time when workers were given their tools in a sack when they left.

@JohnWM 

Where I live, that window seems to be getting smaller all the time.

We have a dogwood festival in Atlanta. This year it's April 13- 15, in Piedmont Park, which has many dogwood trees. It's always been held around that time. When I first moved to the Deep South, in the mid-1970s, that was when the dogwoods bloomed.

But the week or so when the dogwoods bloom has been moving back continuously. It went back to about the first week of April, and stayed there for a long time. Then in started creeping back into March. Last year it jumped back dramatically when they started blooming in late February and the first week of March.

So now we have an annual dogwood festival that's held long after the dogwoods have blossomed. Nobody seems to want to bring up the implications of that. Probably it will eventually get blamed on 'chemtrails' and some secret plot.

@Bruce 
Same thing with the Cherry Blossom Festival in NE Ohio in the 80's-90's...
.  
Easter in Atlanta saw all of us going to church in our new outfits...only it was always too cold and we had to wear our winter coats...1960-65.  I don't recall any Dogwood Festvals, but we usually drove around through Lullwater to view the azaleas in Spring...

@Josh 

Amen! It is just to express honest feelings about any particular crossword puzzle, and it's helpful for the editors and constructors to know a solver's true feelings. Please ignore the nattering know-it-alls and speak your mind.
@Josh Agreed. I rarely post negative comments, but I think there's a place for them here if they are respectful and constructive.

@Josh I certainly think we should feel free to express our opinion, whether favorable or not. And others can  agree or disagree, as long as it‚Äôs respectful and couched as opinion and not unassailable fact (there are a few commenters who do that regularly).

I draw the line at commenters who question the motives of or outright drag the constructors. Calling a constructor lazy or smug is uncalled for. A puzzle didn‚Äôt do it for you? Fine, not all of them will. Just don‚Äôt insult the people who worked hard to offer you something to entertain you. Feel free to tell them why you didn‚Äôt like it - maybe they‚Äôll craft something more to your liking in the future.

@CrispyShot 

I agree with all that's been said on this thread (and am as @Bob T. in rarely posting negative comments).

I agree with what you said most of all! I really loathe the "pot calling the kettle black" posters who leave only a single brief sentence damning a puzzle and its creator. 

That said, bring on the constructive criticism! Thanks @Josh for this thread!

@Josh 

I agree with you. 

I think a big part of the issue is the way in which too many people post their criticisms. I've seen far too many, as CrispyShot mentions, that are just out of line mean and abusive. Commenters accusing constructors of laziness or bad intentions...  or the constructor just thinks they're too clever by half. And worse. I recently saw someone say quite meanly about a debut constructor that this was their first puzzle -- and they hope it's the constructor's last.  Why do that? 

There's just no reason for that. If one doesn't like a puzzle and wishes to say so, that's fine. I feel like most people who express that it wasn't their cup of tea and‚Äîlike a reasonable human to other reasonable humans‚Äîcalmly expresses their opinions without personal attack are usually accepted. 

I don't think I saw the post you mentioned though, so I can't speak to that.

@CrispyShot I couldn‚Äôt agree more. Personal attacks on our constructors (or editors) are never ok. That *should* go without saying, really, but clearly it sometimes needs said. (And yeah, among those ad hominem attacks, ‚Äúlazy‚Äù is perhaps the most vexing!)

@Lynn 

I feel the same as you. So often I struggle with puzzles that others find easy, but I found this puzzle straightforward. I am surprised by so many complaints today, but to each their own.

Because of SExTET instead of SESTET, and not having heard of LAY in that context, I had a hard time coming up with HEARTEYES.  If not for that, and a typo elsewhere, I believe I would have been very close to my Tuesday average.  As it turned out, I was below, but closer to my Wednesday average.  Individual puzzles can be way below or over one's average -- it happens enough that I don't care when it does.  The overall increase in difficulty over the week still exists when you take the average of a large number of times.

@Helen Wright 
Let's see now, The Lays of Beleriand was a Tolkien book, but there's also The Lais of Marie de France. What am I missing? I don't know how French works. LAY was easy enough for me, though.

@B

I didn't know the SHANNON river or LAY (in that context) but both of them filled in very easily for me.

@Jim  completely agree. That was the sector that tripped me up and took ages. Otherwise, the puzzle was decently fair for a Tuesday/Weds. didn‚Äôt really pay much attention to the theme tho.

@Mark I found it pretty straightforward with three or four monsters that really gummed up the works. I finished but had a bad time and was reduced to funneling letters through a couple of words. Nice workout though.

@HeathieJ 

I didn't know the SHANNON river, and I'm also not up on my Korean boy bands.  So the S in Shannon was a total guess--a fairly easy one, but a guess nonetheless.

For what it's worth, I thought it was harder than a typical Tuesday, but I've thought that about other Tuesdays as well.  Like you I got LAY on crosses, but barely.  

But I don't care if I get a Friday on a Tuesday--I'm trying to solve all of them, and it doesn't really matter if it's hard or easy.

@Francis 

It wouldn't matter to me either - I would probably enjoy the unpredictability - were it not for the fact that we're TOLD straight out that this is the progression of difficulty through the week, and that some of us are trying to take advantage of that consistency.  I was trying to introduce others gently to crosswords.  Other people are trying to budget their time / coffee / brain states in line with expected difficulty, or seeking solace/refuge in the easier days.

It's irritating and unfair to have a Tuesday harder than the preceding weekend puzzles.  It's going to turn off learners and newbies.  But of course I know it's subjective and that people like Heathie found it simpler than I did....  Luckily I previewed it before turning it over to the novice to try.

Andrew, Really. As I posted about five hours ago... One person's tricky clue may be another's gimme, but I'm always a bit sad when people push back on clues that are definitions of their answers. lay 4 of 5 noun (2) 1: a simple narrative poem : ballad https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/lay#dictionary-entry-4 P.S. @Barry Ancona I think it's fair to push back on a definition that obscure on a Tuesday.

@Barry Ancona I think the issue lies in that there are far better ways to clue the word LAY, especially for a Tuesday level difficulty.  If it were a Saturday I‚Äôd think it a much more acceptable clue but Tuesdays take me about 4-5 minutes and this one took be about 12 because of some clunky clueing.  

Also, while you can find ‚ÄòBallad‚Äô as a definition of LAY, it doesn‚Äôt work the other way around so checking the dictionary/thesaurus for an obscure definition of ‚ÄòBallad‚Äô didn‚Äôt help in this case.  You‚Äôd have to run the alphabet after LA- and check definitions for EVERY WORD  to see which letter fits the obscure clue (LAB, LAD, LAG etc.), which naturally would take forever to get to Y.  Not exactly the most enjoyable way to learn a new definition.

This word was actually used alot in the nineteenth century, especially under the influence of the PreRaphaelites who tended to paint and write a lot of works romanticizing the Middle Ages, which we today would view as sharply innacurate and overly romantic,but somehow appealing as fairytales are appealing.  If you read any nineteenth -century literature, tomantic or not, you may well come across this synonym for ballad, or chanson de geste.  It is just sn historical word like any other.
